segments.text: of audit and finance will read the audit announcement into the record.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: At the June 13 quarterly audit and finance meeting the office of internal audit presented six internal audit reports.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: The audits included historic Horace Mann school construction follow-up audit, Genesee Hill elementary school design follow-up audit,
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: West Seattle high school audit, ORCA K8 audit, disbursements audit, employee leave time audit.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: All findings and recommendations were discussed at a public audit and finance meeting and the completed reports are available online at the office of internal audits public webpage.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: Click on departments under the district tab then click on internal audit.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: We have now come to the board comments section of the agenda and my fellow colleagues if you would keep in mind what a long and lovely evening this is and if you could keep them short we would be grateful.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: Thank you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: Director Geary.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Director Geary Hello everybody so many of you gone now and I've already spoken several times so I will keep it short.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: short the one thing I haven't spoken on is the ethnic studies proposal and I guess Isabella McMurchie was one of our early students and I don't think anybody could say it as eloquently as she did.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And the idea that ethnic studies is going to benefit everybody and we really do need to make this part of our curriculum in a meaningful way.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Not just necessarily embedding it in history but really figuring out how we are going to make it age appropriate from K-12 in a way that is going to be meaningful and make sure that our kids from all different cultures can come together.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: We had, I want to comment, there was an article out of KUOW, myself and Director Blanford were mentioned somewhat.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And I'm going to stand by, I can't remember there's been so much that's happened since then even that that starts to fade.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Where I thought I was going to come up here and talk about that for some time and I'm not going to other than to say I was sorry that my comment ended with a violent imagery of parents taking up arms because that was never the intent.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: The one thing I do recall saying in that interview that wasn't put out was that it was my experience that shaming parents at this point as we are trying to engage in these conversations isn't going to be the way we are going to move forward in this city that has so much separation.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And so I really appreciate as well Kim Fergus coming with her article because again I think this was an article that was printed and there were some comments about it you know and the voice that it had not being exactly the right voice.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: But it was a voice that dared to throw itself out on a really difficult topic.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And maybe she did it from her view Ridge soccer mom perspective to some degree, but you know that's the start.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And we have to welcome that start and we have to keep inviting those conversations across the lines.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So I was sorry that the article on KUOW had that militant piece because I don't ever want anybody to think that arming or using that imagery in any way is appropriate.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And to the extent that people felt it was shaming, I wouldn't have approved of that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: But I think it is conversations and we have to continue to have them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And that is why I'm going to say Charlene Lyle's name, say her name.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: That is just been, I can't shake it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: It's been a tragedy, my district, you know we go along, it's Northeast Seattle, people you know, don't need to worry about them too much.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: But we do.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: We do.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Because this happened in my district to Charlene Lyles, one of the moms.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Okay thank you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Charlene Lyles.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And I'm going to tie this around because we
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: We need to continue to keep the conversation between the city and the county and the state as we put these families, we create these housing units.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So we have these families in Magnuson and we haven't appropriately supported them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And there are people that continue to go to the city saying you've got to support these kids, you've got to support these families.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And frankly I was surprised it was a mom and not one of the kids that ended up in a conflict with the police.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And we are going to see the same thing happen potentially with Fort Lawton.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And so as we move forward in these conversations, I'm going to say it right now, that's a perspective I'm going to take about what we do when we are placing housing in our affluent neighborhoods, and are the families going to show up and wrap around them?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Or walk away from them?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Is our city going to wrap around them and make sure that they are supported?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Is our county going to do it?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And is our state going to do it?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So we have some opportunities in terms of our Magnuson families coming up.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And I will keep on it and I will let people know when I know we have a good ask.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: But we are going to have to wrap everybody around and I hope
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Our families will show up for that ask, and that they will show up for the Fort Lawton ask, and that we continue these conversations together, not by building barriers between each other.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Thank you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Harris Thank you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: Other directors?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: Director Pinkham.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: I just want to thank all the people that commented tonight and shared their views and perspectives because you are the ones that put us up here in the dais and still listen to your voice and thank you to all of our staff.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: We are all here for the same reasons and you know we are bringing in different views and perspectives and I value that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: Some decisions are going to be tough, some decisions are not so tough but they are decisions that we have to eventually make because we have students out there waiting for us.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: Waiting for us to provide them a place to get educated, waiting for us to let them know that you know we care about them and I want to let them know that yeah we do care about you but
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: I don't know sometimes as adults we get carried away in some of the minutiae I guess we would say.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: But I'm proud to be up here on the board and thank you for electing me to be here and I ask that you bear with us, bear with me as we progress.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: I just want to keep it short saying you know
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: I just see us improving.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: No matter which way we go we are all going to make the Seattle school district a better place for everyone.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: As we embrace ethnic studies, we embrace keeping families together the best that we can, as we embrace the students that we are in charge of.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: I know time is tight but I just want to acknowledge and thank everyone for coming here this evening.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_18

segments.text: Qeciyy Director Burke
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_11

segments.text: Also being brief I want to thank everyone who gave their comments and have shared their input on email.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: We have received a prolific amount of enthusiastic support for
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: for waitlists, for deeper understanding of the Fort Lawton situation and boundaries around that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And I think that the, I come back to this regularly that we on the board are supposed to be operating at the 30,000 foot level.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And the staff also has to implement things that are systemwide.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And really understanding what are the impacts that happen in the schools, we rely on our families, our educators, our students to help us find places where we can make things better.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: Where we've got common problems that we can then look at as systemic problems.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: that we can then try to address at the policy level and improve organizationally.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: We recognize that we are operating at a budget deficit, and it looks like that is going to be our mode for the
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: foreseeable future.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: Which means we have to be really thoughtful and deliberate about what we do.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And I say that as the person who said oh it's just $1.9 million.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: So I recognize I'm talking out of both sides of my mouth there, but what we have to do is we have to be thoughtful about the services we are providing to our families, the importance of stability, the importance of maintaining
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: Our families, keeping them in the district, keeping the revenue going, keeping our schools at high and consistent levels of enrollment so that we don't have staff turnover.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: When we have to turn over staff in schools we bear costs to recruit, retain, train, the schools have the disruption of bringing new people on, having to cut people.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: The sort of disruption and churn that is created by our funding and some of our policies is sort of a self-fulfilling prophecy.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: Where we create situations, or situations are created for us, we should not take all the blame for it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: A lot of it is the state and funding.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: But these situations drive us to make decisions that are disruptive, and then we end up in a reactionary mode.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And we don't have the time or the focus to fix it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And so I think people bringing things to us with a level of intensity that we can identify common problems, but also with the recognition that we are working at a system level.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And sometimes it takes a little bit longer.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: And I'm grateful for the people who have shared that with me, that that's sort of their perspective.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: I know that around the Fort Lawton, the enthusiasm of the community and of the board, and of the staff, we are engaging with the city to try to understand what we have for placeholders there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: Whether it is a short-term thing, it doesn't look like we actually have a short-term need, but to have a potential piece of property that could be a school is something that we have to consider in the long-term.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: I will defer on my topic level discussions to when we are introducing the items around ethnic studies, some of the other great things that are coming up, we have an assessment policy that is being introduced, and also the career and technical education annual report and plan coming out of the curriculum and instruction committee.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: So I will speak a little bit to those when they are introduced.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: I wanted to just say in closing that I had the pleasure, thank you to my colleague Director
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: gifting me with two of her graduations at Chief Sealth and West Seattle while she was out of state on a work-related event.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: For me not having any high schools it's great to be able to experience the enthusiasm and energy that permeates those events.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: It's really uplifting to see the kids and how excited they are about their journey and their future.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: So thank you to the community, thank you to the colleagues, thank you to staff and I hope everybody has a wonderful summer.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22

segments.text: If we don't see you on the 5th.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_22
